facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1956 was filed as an appeal by special leave from the orders dated January 25, 1955, of the Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 203 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the orders dated January 25, 1955, of the Madras High Court in C.M.P. No. 9335 of 1954 and S. R. No. 55247 of 1953.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on November 28, 1957 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. November 28. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.-This is a plaintiffs appeal by special leave against the order passed by a Division Bench of the Madras High Court on January 25, 1955, 1023 calling upon him to pay companyrt fees on the valuation of Rs. 15,00,000 both on his plaint and on his memorandum of appeal and it raises some interesting questions of law under the provisions of the Court Fees Act  which will be described hereafter as the Act .

facts.text: Appellant filed Civil Suit No. 311 of 1951 on the Original Side of the Madras High Court claiming partition of joint family properties and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant bad filed Civil Suit No. 311 of 1951 on the Original Side of the Madras High Court. In this suit be had claimed partition of the joint family, properties and an account in respect of the joint family assets managed by the respondent.

facts.text: The appellant is the son of Subbiah Chettiar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the son of Subbiah Chettiar. His case was that Subbiah had been adopted by Lakshmi Achi in 1922.

facts.text: Subbiah Chettiar was adopted by Lakshmi Achi in 1922.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that Subbiah had been adopted by Lakshmi Achi in 1922. Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent.

facts.text: Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshmi Achi was the widow of the undivided paternal uncle of the respondent. As a result of his adoption Subbiah became a companyarcener in his adoptive family and, as Subbiahs son, the appellant claimed to have a share in the joint family properties and in the assets of the joint family and that was the basis on which a claim for partition and accounts was made by the appellant in his suit.

facts.text: Subbiah filed a suit for partition of his share and obtained a decree in the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: In the plaint it had been alleged that Subbiah had filed a suit for partition of his share and had obtained a decree in the trial companyrt.

facts.text: The respondent took an appeal against the decree obtained by Subbiah.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had taken an appeal against the said decree in the High Court. Pending the appeal the dispute was settled amicably between the parties

facts.text: Pending the appeal, the dispute was settled amicably; Subbiah agreed to release all claims of himself and his son in consideration of payment of a specified sum and delivery of possession of certain sites.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the appeal the dispute was settled amicably between the parties and in companysideration of payment of a specified sum and delivery of possession of certain sites Subbiah agreed to release all his claims and those of his son, the present appellant, in respect of the properties then in suit.

facts.text: Appellant claimed the compromise transaction did not bind him.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, this companypromise transaction did number bind the appellant and so he claimed to recover his share ignoring the said transaction between his father and the respondent.

facts.text: Chamber Judge Krishnaswamy Naidu J. decided on October 18, 1951 that court fee under Art. 17-B Schedule II was correct.

anchor.surface_text: This reference was decided by the Chamber Judge Krishnaswamy Naidu J. on October 18, 1951. The learned judge held that the appellant was number bound to set aside the prior companypromise decree between his father and the respondent and that the plaint was governed by Art. 17-B of Schedule 11.

facts.text: Ramaswamy Gounder J. dismissed the suit on September 22, 1953 holding appellant bound by the compromise decree.

anchor.surface_text: Ramaswamy Gounder J. who heard the suit tried the respondents companytention about the binding character of the companypromise decree as a preliminary issue. The learned judge held that there was a fair and bona fide settlement of the dispute by the appellants father acting as the manager of his branch and so the appellant was bound by the companypromise decree. In the result, the appellants suit was dismissed on September 22, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant filed memorandum of appeal on December 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree the appellant presented his memorandum of appeal on December 1, 1953. This memorandum bore the same companyrt fees as the plaint.

facts.text: Division Bench of Madras High Court on reference held that s.7(iv)(b) applies and directed valuation of partition relief.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits the learned judges agreed with the view taken by Krishnaswamy Naidu J., and held that s. 7 v  of the Act was number applicable to the appellants claim for partition. According to the learned judges, neither was Art. 17-B of Schedule II applicable. They held that the provisions of s. 7 iv  b  of the Act applied.

facts.text: Appellant valued partition relief at Rs. 50,000 and paid deficit court fee on May 7, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In companypliance with this order the appellant valued 1026 his relief to enforce his right to share in the joint family properties in suit at Rs. 50,000, paid the deficit companyrt fee Rs. 1,662-7-0 and re-presented his memorandum of appeal in companyrt on May 7, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant made application to amend plaint valuation on October 18, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the appellant made an application on October 18,1954. This application was opposed both by the respondent and the Assistant Government Pleader on behalf of the State.

facts.text: Division Bench rejected amendment application and directed payment of court fees on Rs. 15,00,000 on plaint and memorandum of appeal under s.12(2).

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges who heard this application took the view that if the appellant had given the value in the first instance for purposes of jurisdiction he was precluded from giving a different value at a later stage. Accordingly it was held that Rs. 15,00,000, which had been mentioned in the plaint as the value of the appellants claim for jurisdictional purposes should be treated as the value given by the appellant also for the purposes of companyrt fees under s. 7 iv  b  of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant valued claim for accounts at Rs. 1,000 and paid ad valorem fee of Rs. 112-7-0.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint filed by the appellant valued the claim for accounts at Rs. 1,000 under s. 7 iv  f  of the Act and a companyrt fee of Rs. 112-7-0 was paid on the said amount on an ad valorem basis.

facts.text: For partition relief, appellant paid fixed court fee of Rs. 100 under Art. 17-B Schedule II.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the relief for partition the fixed companyrt fee of Rs. 100 was paid by the appellant under Art. 17-B  Madras  of Schedule II of the Act.

facts.text: For jurisdiction, appellant gave value of Rs. 15,00,000 as his share.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of jurisdiction, however, the appel- lant gave Rs. 15,00,000 as the value of his share.

facts.text: Respondent contended that the compromise and release deed were fair and bona fide and bound the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: One of the points raised by the respondent was -that the companypromise and the release deed executed by the appellants father and the decree that was subsequently passed between the parties were fair and bona fide transactions and, since they amounted to a settlement of the disputed claim by the appellants father, the plaintiff was bound by them.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the order of Division Bench under s.5 on s.7(iv)(b) applicability is final.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the decision of the Division Bench of the Madras High Court that the memorandum of appeal should be taxed for the purposes of companyrt fee under s. 7 iv  b  of the Act is final under the provisions of s.5 of the Act and it cannot be reopened at this stage.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside the order and allowed appellant to value relief at Rs. 50,000 for court fees on plaint.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the order under appeal and direct that the plaintiff should be allowed to state the amount of Rs. 50,000 at which he values the relief sought by him for the purpose of s. 7 iv  b  of the Act.

facts.text: No record showed appointment of Krishnaswamy Naidu J. under s.5 by Chief Justice.

anchor.surface_text: They held that the record did number show that Krishnaswamy Naidu J. had been numberinated by the Chief Justice to. hear the reference under s. 5 either by a general or a special order and so numberfinality companyld be claimed for the said order under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant paid deficit court fee of Rs. 1,662-7-0 after valuing at Rs. 50,000.

anchor.surface_text: paid the deficit companyrt fee Rs. 1,662-7-0 and re-presented his memorandum of appeal in companyrt on May 7, 1954.
Appeal by special leave from the orders dated January 25, 1955, of the Madras High Court in C.M.P. No. 9335 of 1954 and S. R. No. 55247 of 1953.
The plaint filed by the appellant valued the claim for accounts at Rs. 1,000 under s. 7 iv  f  of the Act and a court fee of Rs. 112-7-0 was paid on the said amount on an ad valorem basis.
In regard to the relief for partition the fixed court fee of Rs. 100 was paid by the appellant under Art. 17-B  Madras  of Schedule II of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the order passed by the learned Chamber Judge on October 18, 1951, is final under s. 5 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first point which Shri Krishnaswamy Ayyangar has raised before us on behalf of the appellant is that the order passed by the learned Chamber Judge on October 18, 1951, is final under s. 5 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the learned judges were in error in purporting to exercise their jurisdiction under s. 12(2) of the Act when they directed the appellant to pay additional court fees on the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: It is then urged by Shri Krishnaswamy Ayyangar that the learned judges were in error in purporting to exercise their jurisdiction under s. 12 2  of the Act when they directed the appellant to pay additional companyrt fees on the plaint on the basis of the valuation of Rs. 15,00,000.

issues.text: Whether s. 12 of the Act applies to appeals arising from judgments and decrees passed in suits on the Original Side of the Madras High Court via the Madras High Court Fees Rules.

anchor.surface_text: His companytention is that s. 12 does number apply to the appeals arising from judgments and decrees passed in suits on the Original Side of the Madras High Court. It is perfectly true that the question about the levy of fees in High Courts on their Original Sides is governed by s. 3 of the Act

issues.text: Whether the Division Bench was justified in directing the appellant to pay court fees both on the plaint and on the memorandum of appeal on the basis of the valuation of Rs. 15,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: The question which still remains to be companysidered is whether the Division Bench was justified in directing the appellant to pay companyrt fees both on the plaint and on the memorandum of appeal on the basis of the  valuation for Rs. 15,00,000.

issues.text: Whether in suits under s. 7(iv)(b) of the Court Fees Act, the valuation for jurisdiction determines the court fee or the plaintiff's valuation for court fees determines the jurisdictional value.

anchor.surface_text: This question has to be decided by reading s. 7 of the Act along with s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed not bound but Art.17-B rejected; s.7(iv)(b) instead.

holdings.text: The order passed by Krishnaswamy Naidu J. on October 18, 1951 under s.5 is not final because the record does not show any general or special appointment by the Chief Justice.

anchor.surface_text: They held that the record did not show that Krishnaswamy Naidu J. had been nominated by the Chief Justice to. hear the reference under s. 5 either by a general or a special order and so nofinality could be claimed for the said order under s. 5 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 requires appointment by Chief Justice; record search shows no such general or special order; practice assumption insufficient without record evidence.

holdings.text: The Division Bench was justified in exercising jurisdiction under s.12(1) and (2) to determine adequacy of court fees on plaint and memorandum of appeal in Original Side suits via Madras High Court Fees Rules O.11 r.1 and O.II r.1.

anchor.surface_text: on the plaints filed on the Original Side of the Madras High Court, court fees are leviable under the relevant provisions contained in Chapter III of the Act and the levy of these fees is authorised by O. 11, r. I

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.11 r.1 levies Chapter III fees; O.II r.1 extends Act provisions including s.12 for scale, levy, refund 'in every other respect' to Original Side suits/appeals; logical to check sufficiency if levy applies.

holdings.text: s.12 applies to appeals from Original Side suits of Madras High Court through extension by Madras High Court Fees Rules.

anchor.surface_text: on the plaints filed on the Original Side of the Madras High Court, court fees are leviable under the relevant provisions contained in Chapter III of the Act and the levy of these fees is authorised by O. 11, r. I

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3 governs Original Side but rules O.11 r.1 and O.II r.1 expressly apply Chapter III and Act provisions 'in every other respect' including appellate power under s.12.

holdings.text: The Division Bench decision that s.7(iv)(b) applies (not s.7(v) or Art.17-B Sch.II) is final under s.5 as decided by Bench constituted by Chief Justice.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the decision of the Division Bench of the Madras High Court that the memorandum of appeal should be taxed for the purposes of court fee under s. 7 iv  b  of the Act is final under the provisions of s.5 of the Act and it cannot be reopened at this stage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference by Master under s.5 to Chief Justice who constituted Division Bench; decision final per s.5; merits not reopened even if respondent not heard unless jurisdiction involved.

holdings.text: In suits under s.7(iv)(b), plaintiff states value of relief for court fees; that value determines jurisdiction value under SVA s.8 (not vice versa); liberty to amend plaint valuation for fees.

anchor.surface_text: This question has to be decided by reading s. 7 of the Act along with s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7(iv)(b) gives plaintiff option to value due to difficulty in precise valuation of undivided share to separate share; SVA s.8 makes jurisdiction value same as fees value; fees primary.

holdings.text: Division Bench not justified in directing court fees on Rs.15,00,000 (jurisdiction value) for plaint and memo of appeal under s.7(iv)(b); must use plaintiff's Rs.50,000 fees valuation.

anchor.surface_text: The question which still remains to be considered is whether the Division Bench was justified in directing the appellant to pay court fees both on the plaint and on the memorandum of appeal on the basis of the  valuation for Rs. 15,00,000.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior final order under s.7(iv)(b) allows plaintiff valuation Rs.50,000 for fees; jurisdiction follows fees value per SVA s.8; error to bind by initial jurisdiction value without amendment opportunity.

holdings.text: Set aside Division Bench order of 25.1.1955; allow plaintiff to value partition relief at Rs.50,000 under s.7(iv)(b) for court fees on plaint; liberty to amend granted.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly set aside the order under appeal and direct that the plaintiff should be allowed to state the amount of Rs. 50,000 at which he values the relief sought by him for the purpose of s. 7 iv  b  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings to facts; appellant paid deficit on Rs.50,000 for appeal; consistent treatment for plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Karam Ilahi v. Muhammad Bashir 1 . As we have already indicated s. 8 of the Suits Valuation Act postulates that the plaintiff should first value his claim for the purpose of companyrt fee

precedents.cited_proposition: it would not be reasonable or proper in such a case to hold the plaintiff bound by the valuation made by him for the purposes of jurisdiction and to infer that the said valuation should be also taken as the valuation for the payment of court fees

justification_sets.label: Madras High Court Fees Rules 1933 Order 11 Rule 1 support
Madras High Court Fees Rules 1933 Order 11 Rule 1 support

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal would be allowed and the appellant directed to pay additional court fees on his plaint on the basis of the valuation of Rs. 50,000 within two months from today.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; order of Madras High Court Division Bench set aside; liberty granted to amend plaint valuation to Rs. 50,000 under s.7(iv)(b) of Court Fees Act for court fees purposes on plaint and memorandum of appeal; directed to pay additional court fees on plaint based on Rs. 50,000 valuation.
directions: set aside the order under appeal
plaintiff allowed to state amount of Rs. 50,000 as value of relief under s.7(iv)(b)
